sub_title: Assistant Professor of Social Science Research Methods; Storyteller
summary:
I am an Assistant Professor in the Department of Public Administration and Sociology at Erasmus University of Rotterdam (NL). I conduct research into the social and economic consequences of family change for individuals and societies in the Europe and the United States. I lead the Population and Society team within the Erasmus School of Social and Behavioral Sciences strategic pillar Global Social Challenges. I teach courses in empirical sociology, social demography and quantitative methods at the Bachelors and Masters levels.

I am an International Collaborator with the Linnaeus Center on Social Policy and Family Dynamics in Europe (Stockholm University) and with the "The Family Lives of Children of Immigrants in Norway" project (Statistics Norway).

Previously I was a Lecturer (Assistant Professor) in Social Statistics and Demography at the University of Southampton (UK) and a postdoctoral researcher at the Netherlands Interdisciplinary Demographic Institute.

In 2011, I completed a doctoral dissertation in Sociology at the University of Wisconsin-Madison entitled "Why Do? The meaning of marriage in the Nordic countries."

Expertise: 
Social and Formal Demography
Family Sociology
Migration and Migrant Populations
Comparative Cross-National: Europe and the United States
Public Policy
Social Science Research Methods
